properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: The first accumulating snowfall of the season. Snow has begun north of Lake Superior and will continue to spread northeast this evening. Snow will taper off by Sunday morning. Current indications suggest snowfall amounts near 10 cm are possible. However, uncertainty remains high with temperatures near zero degrees. Heavy snow could affect road conditions and visibilities. Be prepared to adjust your driving with changing road conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-18T12:20:10-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-17T20:21:10-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2279966859.2020

properties.Summary:
Description: The first accumulating snowfall of the season. Snow will continue to spread northeast tonight. The snow will taper off from southwest to northeast beginning this evening. Current indications suggest total snowfall amounts of up to 5 cm are possible. Brief heavy snow could affect road conditions and visibilities. Be prepared to adjust your driving with changing road conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A low pressure system from the Eastern American Seaboard will move across Eastern Quebec today. This system will bring between 30 and 50 millimetres of rain over several areas of Eastern Quebec. Rain will end this evening over the Gasp√© peninsula and the North Shore and Sunday morning over the Lower North Shore. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: The first accumulating snowfall of the season. Snow will continue to spread northeast tonight. The snow will taper off from southwest to northeast overnight. Current indications suggest snowfall amounts of 4 to 8 cm are possible. However, with warmer temperatures and a mix of rain and snow expected near Lake Superior, snowfall amounts could be much less along the lakeshore. Heavy snow could affect road conditions and visibilities. Be prepared to adjust your driving with changing road conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: The first accumulating snowfall of the season will begin tonight. Snow has begun north of Lake Superior and will continue to spread northeast tonight. Snow will taper off Sunday afternoon. Current indications suggest snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are possible. However, the highest amounts are likely in a narrow band that may miss most communities. Attawapiskat and Ogoki Post may receive near 5 cm of snow, while Lansdowne House may receive closer to 2 cm. Heavy snow could affect road conditions and visibilities. Be prepared to adjust your driving with changing road conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-18T12:17:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-17T20:18:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2588378838.2020
Area: Attawapiskat, Fort Hope - Lansdowne House - Ogoki
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Persistent snow squalls are expected. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Lake Winnipeg North Basin snow squall activity will intensify tonight as northwest winds combine with a push of colder air into the region. These squalls will move southeastwards off the lake, primarily into the Berens River and Bloodvein areas. The snow squalls will persist through Sunday and into Monday before tapering off. Snowfall accumulations may be highly variable across short distances, but accumulations of 15 cm in 12 hours will be possible and some areas may see event total snowfalls as high as 25 to 30 cm by the time it tapers off on Monday. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snow squall warnings are issued when bands of snow form that produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-18T12:31:17-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-17T20:32:17-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1654046239.2020
Area: Berens River, Bloodvein
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. Heavy snow will develop in Qikiqtarjuaq on Sunday as a winter storm system moves towards Baffin Island. Snow will begin on Sunday morning and last until it changes to rain sometime on Sunday evening. Before this change-over, Qikiqtarjuaq will see 10 to 20 cm of snow. Rain will persist through Sunday night and will likely erode much of the snowpack. During the day on Sunday, visibilities may be significantly reduced in heavy snow. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-18T11:32:03-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-17T19:33:03-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2984584445.2020
Area: Qikiqtarjuaq
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Periods of heavy rain is expected today and tonight. Time frame: today and this evening. Locations: northwestern New Brunswick. Total rainfall amounts: near 50 mm. Remarks: Rain at times heavy will end before midnight tonight. Additionally, there is likely to be some wet snow mixing with the rain over higher terrain this evening before it ends. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Be prepared for possible winter conditions at higher elevations. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-18T03:59:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-17T13:54:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1474725802.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wreckhouse Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds are expected or occurring. Maximum wind gusts: southeasterly between 100 and 120 km/h Time span: continuing until late overnight. Location: Wreckhouse area. Remarks: Winds are gusting near 90 km/h, and will gradually increase to 120 km/h near midnight. Winds will ease upon shifting to westerly before Sunday morning. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Wreckhouse wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-10-18T09:59:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-18T01:05:20-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1203597364.2020

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High westerly winds gusting up to 100 kilometres per hour are expected over these areas overnight tonight. They will gradually diminish beginning early Sunday morning. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
